title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". The Congress acknowledges that Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are rapidly increasing in the U.S., affecting all demographic groups. The rate of autism has risen from 1 in 10,000 in the 1980s to 1 in 150 currently, indicating an epidemic. A new case of autism is diagnosed every 20 minutes, surpassing the diagnoses of AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined. The economic cost of autism to the nation is over $35 billion annually. Autism costs the Nation over $35 billion annually, with costs expected to rise. The lack of preparedness in educational, labor, housing, and medical sectors to support individuals with autism could lead to a loss of future talent in various fields. Despite being a pressing societal issue, autism research receives less than 5 percent of federal funding compared to other childhood diseases. In December 2006, Congress passed the "Combating Autism Act of 2006," committing nearly $1 billion to autism research, including studies on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. A White House Conference on Autism aims to advance research on cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. The authorization of the conference is stated in Section 3. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating autism in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing will plan and conduct the Conference to find the underlying causes of autism. The White House Conference on Autism aims to identify causes, provide solutions and services for autistic individuals and families, conduct comprehensive research, facilitate national dialogue, and highlight effective programs for autistic children and adults. The White House Conference on Autism aims to review existing legislation and programs at all levels to improve services for autistic individuals and their families. Recommendations for legislative action will be developed to enhance health and quality of life for autistic individuals. Recommendations for legislative action will be developed to enhance health and quality of life for autistic individuals. Establishment of a Policy Committee with 17 members, including presidential appointees and house appointees, to address the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States. Among these members, there are specific requirements for expertise in areas such as autism intervention programs, educational needs, housing needs, and law enforcement training. The Policy Committee for addressing the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States consists of 17 members, including presidential and house appointees. Senate and House leaders select members after consulting with relevant committees. 50 percent of the appointed members must have special qualifications. The committee is specifically designed to train and educate law enforcement and criminal justice officials to respond to the unique needs of children and adults with autism. Additionally, at least one member must be knowledgeable about environmental or toxic exposure as it relates to the development of autism. The Surgeon General serves as the chairperson of the Policy Committee, with voting done by a majority of members present and a quorum required for conducting business. The Policy Committee's duties include meeting at the call of the Cochairs within 30 days. The Policy Committee, consisting of 17 members, meets at the call of the Cochairs within 30 days. They make recommendations for the Conference agenda, delegates, and establish an executive committee to work with Conference delegates. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds related to autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and individuals affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States.

SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide notice to all Policy Committee members of meetings, request cooperation from other Federal departments, make proposed agendas available for public comment, and prepare necessary background materials for delegates. The Cochairs have the authority to provide necessary resources for Conference delegates and hire additional personnel as needed. They are also responsible for ensuring that the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register and that the employed personnel represent a balanced range of viewpoints. The Cochairs of the Conference ensure a balanced representation of viewpoints and independence from political influence. They gather necessary data on autism spectrum disorders and evaluate federal programs before convening the Conference. The Cochairs of the Conference may accept gifts, including cash or services, to support the Act. They must keep records of the gifts received and the assistance provided to individuals. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state chief executive officers. States must submit their views on the report within 45 days. A final report, including state executives' views, must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment and submitted to the President and Congress. The Policy Committee must prepare a report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be sent to state chief executive officers. States must submit their views within 45 days. A final report, including state executives' views, must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment and submitted to the President and Congress for action. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS.

The Surgeon General must prepare and publish a status report on the implementation of recommendations within 2 years of the Conference adjournment. The Comptroller General must also prepare and publish subsequent status reports every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved. These reports will be transmitted to the President and Congress. SEC. 9. DEFINITION OF STATE. The term "State" in this Act refers to several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, or the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization is granted for necessary appropriations to carry out the Act, with limitations on new spending authority. Funds appropriated and received as gifts are available for use, except as specified. Funds appropriated for the Act and gifts received shall be available for 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Unspent funds after this period will be returned to the Treasury, unless a trust fund is established for a future Autism Conference if the current one is not convened before December 31, 2010.
